Sounds like swerve drift, it might be a problem with one of the swerve motors from my experience. Try putting the robot on its side an testing all the drive positions to see if one of the wheels is driving slower than the others or something

Are you guys using yagsl? If so, You might find it helpful to try modifying the angular velocity compensation value.

From your code, it does seem that you’re using yagsl. I would start here.

swerveDrive.setAngularVelocityCompensation( true, true, -0.1);

Something like this, depending on what you’ve named your swerve drive object.

Yes, you would put this in your constructor in the SwerveSubsystem.java file.

Literally the first thing to test here is if your wheels are aligned.

Put the robot on its side, enable, drive straight forward, disable while driving, place a straight edge across the wheel forks.

I am willing to bet one of them will be tilted 2 or 3 degrees relative to the others.

docs.yagsl.com
